Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of deer, ibex or gazelle (?). Head only with horns missing. Hand-made and solid. Coated with white slip, then painted with purple-brown detail on eyes. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey-brown core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Possibly made at Naukratis. Resembles Cypriot Archaic (6th to 5th century BC) style figures from Naukratis at the British Museum (GR 1911,0606.2, GR 1888,0601.92). See also NA624, NA365, NA574 and NA625 in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology. 'Early Archaic' parallel from Lindos (Blinkenberg 1931, pl.84, no.1899). The form and the decoration look Archaic Greek in style. Hand-made quadruped animals were made by adding sausages of clay, and pinching or impressing details to the clay. Relatively poorly represented at Naukratis (Museum of Fine Arts, Boston RES.87.219, RES.87.217, 86.423; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge GR.15.1899, GR.37.1887, E.237.1899; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford AN1896- 1908-E.4788, AN1886.507; Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge NA626, NA624), considering this is usually a common figure in Late Period Nile Delta sites. The animals primarily represent bulls or cows, though rams may also be represented and this is not always clear. Parallels from Late Period Kom Firin (Spencer 2013, 176, F556, F644, F855, F677, F588, F490, F653, many may represent horses or riders), Tell el-Balamun (Spencer 1996 , pl.75, nos. 80-1), Memphis (Thomas & Nicholson 2013, 42, P-3; Petrie Museum, UC48296, UC48322; Petrie 1909a, Anthes 1965, pl.49, no.252;pl.44; Petrie 1909d, pl. xix; Anthes 1965, pl.49 c.252; Giddy 1999, pl.68, nos. 245, 343, 429), 5th to 3rd century BC Mendes (Redford 1988, 69, fig.83-4, nos. 771, 786, 785; 1991, 67) Ashmunein (Spencer 1993, nos.222, 233, 220, 195), Tanis (Brissaud 1994. Fig.9c; Brissaud 1995, 31, Fig.3a) and Yehudiyeh (Petrie 1909, pl.19). Anthes, R., Habachi, l., Yoyotte, J. and Jacquet, J. 1965. Mit Rahineh, 1956.
